body.p: I have received your letter in town when I am just in the humour for letter writing and fill up my last scrap of paper for you. I am sorry the Sheffield People do not like the Church; though I am looking for an entirely new class of Readers. My first No converted a fine fellow of a Clergyman here in town and he is quite in raptures. I have received a visit, paid him a visit and have had three notes from him. His name has appeared in public as the Curate of Swalecliffe. It is Claiborne an American born whose father was one of the strugglers for Independence and intimate with Paine.

I left Manchester on Easter [[2]] Sunday spent that evening in conflict with the Socialists of Liverpool ; got to Bolton the next day to meet Acland in the Bolton Theatre. â€” Came on to Birmingham; from that I spent eight days with my new and good friends in Gloucestershire, where I was superlatively happy. have been in London three weeks come sunday laying the foundation of "the Church". Am now going off to WisbeachWisbech, Norwich &c. I assure you I am very happy and very much at ease in my mind. The few friends I have are worth all the rest of the world.

I met Rigby at Hyde a week or so before I left. He had not much chance with me. In Liverpool I quite [[3]] electrified the party coming suddenly and unexpectedly upon them. The People I know will run after hobbies[?] and promises of this kind, having no mind for more solid things. They are using my room in Manchester ; so far good. Owenism is the best of isms as it has no superstition in it. I shall be sending you a WisbeachWisbech Paper when I get there or any thing that comes in my way interesting. T.P.C. is about to attempt a shop in Manchester ; but he is pressing me for what I have not to give him. I will not forget your Diegesis and Volney's Researches. I have them both in my eye.
I shall not return to Lancashire until July and then by route of Cheltenham , Worcester, Birmingham [[4]] &c.

Joseph Harris came to see me on sunday. His breaking up at Newcastle was a bad job, foolish job, al his property will be wasted in law expences. Joseph says it was the father's doing. The father arrested him in London, got a cognovit[?], and off he set to Newcastle. Joseph did not go back again.
Am glad to gear your disconsolate family is in comparatively good health. Joseph Harris knew not of Thomas' death and was thinking of writing to him.
Adieu until we write or meet again.
